attributes.title: Douglas Community Fire
attributes.description: A collaborative project to investigate the experiences and impact of a major fire causing the closure of a community centre in the South of Ireland

q1.value: Out of Business. A survey investigation of the individual and community experiences and impact of the Douglas Village Shopping Centre Fire in Cork

q2.value: Marica Cassarino, Gillian Murphy, Annalisa Setti, Jason Chan, Eleanor Bantry-White

q3.value:
In August 2019, a major fire caused the closure of a shopping centre in Douglas, a suburban area of Cork city (Ireland). The  centre provided the community with a crucial space for a variety of leisure and utility activities. The Douglas Shopping Centre fire offers a unique opportunity to investigate the cognitive/affective experiences and the psychological/social impact of place loss from the perspective of both residents in the community and people working in the centre.
The aim of this collaborative research project is to investigate the use and meaning of the place for people living in the area or employed in the shopping centre, and the impact of the shopping centre closure on activities and wellbeing at two points in time (before and after re-opening of the centre), looking also at the role of individual sociodemographic characteristics (e.g., age) and cognitive processing (e.g., memory accuracy for the event). 
Key research questions include: 
1)	How was the shopping centre used (user type, destinations, frequency of use) and what meaning (Sense of place) did it have for individuals either using the centre as customers or working in the centre before the fire, considering the role of socio-demographic circumstances (e.g., age, functional capability, car access)
2)	Is the type of use of the centre associated with variations in sense of place? 
3)	How does event memory, flashbulb memory and emotional memory change after the reopening of the centre, and how is this related to sense of place, frequency of use, wellbeing, etc.?
4)	How does sense of place relate to the accuracy of remembered emotions concerning the fire?
5)	How did the closure of the shopping centre impact the individual (considering socio-demographic circumstances) in terms of everyday activities (utility and leisure; i.e. agency) and wellbeing (belonging)
6)	 What is the individual’s perceived impact of the centre closure on the community?
7)	Does perceived impact change over time?

q4.value:
The study hypotheses are linked to the specific objectives: 

H1: Sense of place for the centre will be stronger for people who used the centre more frequently, particularly older people living in the local community.

H2: There will be variations in sense of place between users and employees of the shopping centre, with stronger sense of place for those both using the centre as customers and working there. 

H3: Memory accuracy for the fire will be higher for those more attached to the centre as well as those using it more frequently. 

H4: Memory accuracy for the emotions experienced during the fire will be higher for those more attached to the centre

H5: The closure of the centre after the fire will have impacted more negatively those employed in the centre rather than those using it as users; however, people with vulnerabilities (e.g., older people with no car access) would also be more negatively impacted than others. 

H6: People living in the community around the centre will report a higher negative impact of the centre closure for the community than those not living in the area

H7: Perceptions of negative impact will decrease after the centre re-opening

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will use an observational design with both cross-sectional and longitudinal analyses to address the above research questions. Individuals’ experiences will be investigated both qualitatively and quantitatively via an ad hoc survey developed by the research group

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants
The study focuses on a targeted population (i.e., individuals using or working in the Douglas shopping centre before the fire); thus, we will employ purposive and snowball sampling to include all adults aged ≥18 years who identify themselves as customers and/or employees of the shopping centre and who can communicate in English language. 
Participant recruitment will be carried out using a number of channels: 1) We will liaise with the shopping centre management (which has already collaborated with members of the research team in previous project) to advertise the survey through their channels; 2) A local newspaper (Echo Live) will be contacted to write a brief article about the study including a link to the survey); 3) we will share the survey online via social media and mailing lists accessible to the research team (e.g., UCC mailing list); 4) we will contact local groups known to the research team (e.g., Young at Heart active retirement group; Douglas GAA); 5) we will distribute in the local community a flyer including a QR code that will give access to online survey, as well as include contact details for the research team.

Ethics
The study has received ethical approval from the School of Applied Psychology Ethics Committee in February 2020 (ref: STF 0402202005). All prospective participants will be asked to read an information sheet included in the survey cover sheet and to indicate that they consent to take part of the study before accessing the survey. 

Data Collection
Participants will be invited to complete the survey online (Qualtrics XM) or in pen & paper at two points in time (once before and once after the re-opening of the shopping centre) to explore changes in experiences and impact over time (questions 4 & 7). In order to harmonise the data from the two data points, participants will be invited at the end of the survey to leave their email address; this will be used to send the second survey to the same participants and allow for longitudinal analyses.

q13.value: Given the correlational design of the study a power analysis using G-power indicated that a minimum of 134 participants would be needed to achieve an effect size |p| = 0.30, with two-tailed alpha level = 0.05 and power = 0.95.

q15.value:
The first wave of data collection must occur before the re-opening of the centre, thus, data collection for wave 1 will be stopped once the centre re-opens (anticipated Summer 2020). 
A stop to data collection may be decided by the research team in the event that no further individuals are accessed through the recruitment channels described above.

question.value:
Measures
The survey is comprised of four parts that explore: 
1) The use and meaning of the shopping centre (questions 1 & 2); sense of place will be investigated using a scale developed based on previous research on sense of place for shopping locations (Boerebach, 2012) 
2) The memory of the fire (questions 3 & 4), including episodic memory, flashbulb memory, emotional memory, as used in previous research (Murphy, Loftus, Grady, Levine, & Greene, 2019); 
3) The impact of the shopping centre closure on the individual’s activities and wellbeing as well as the community (questions 5-7); wellbeing will be assessed using the The Warwick-Edinburgh mental wellbeing scale (WEMWBS) – 14 items (Tennant et al., 2007), for which permission to use has been granted by the scale creators.
4) Socio-demographic and health characteristics (moderating factors).

The sense of place scale is scored by adding up the score for each of the 10 items, which are coded from 1 - Totally disagree to 5 - Totally agree. Items 7 and 10 need to be reversed before adding up. The total score can go from 10 to 50. 

The total score for the 14-item scale WEMWBS  is obtained by summing the score for each of the 14 items. The scoring range for each item is from 1 – 5 and the total score is from 14-70.

The data collected will be analysed both cross-sectionally and longitudinally. 
Qualitative data (questions 1, 5, 6) will be analysed employing thematic coding. The research team will develop a coding scheme; two members of the research team will code the data independently to identify the core dimensions related to use, meaning and impact. Inter-coder reliability will be measured using Krippendorf f’s alpha (Lavrakas, 2013). A pilot coding will be conducted on a sub-sample of participants’ responses to test and adjust the coding scheme. Codes will then be integrated into the quantitative analysis as categorical measures (i.e., frequencies and percentages of mentions). 
Quantitative data will be described using frequencies and percentages for categorical measures, means and standard deviation (SD) for continuous measures, median and interquartile range (IQR) for ordinal measures. 
Associations between use and meaning, as well as variations in use and meaning by socio-demographic characteristics (questions 1 and 2) will be explored using chi-square test for categorical variables (e.g., gender differences), one-way Analysis of Variance (Anova) or factorial Anova for continuous variables (e.g., age) and Anova with bootstrapping for non-normally distributed measures. 
Associations between sense of place and memory accuracy (question 3) will be explored by conducting comparisons between participants who accurately recall the date of the event and those who don’t, using independent samples t-test or Mann-Whitney test as nonparametric alternative, as well as correlation for continuous or ordinal scales. A factorial anova or nonparametric alternative will be employed to conduct a multivariate analysis controlling for age, functional capability. 
Changes in memory for the event (accuracy, question 4) will be tested within subjects by comparing participants’ accounts of the event at the two different points in time; logistic regression with fixed effects unadjusted and adjusted for socio-demographic characteristics will be used for categorical variables, whereas a repeated measures Anova will be employed for continuous variables and Anova with bootstrapping for ordinal variables. 
Time variations in perceived personal and community impact (questions 5- 7), once coded, will be analysed within subjects looking at changes in the participants’ accounts between the two time points; this analysis will employ a logistic or multinomial regression with fixed effects unadjusted and adjusted for socio-demographic characteristics. Changes in wellbeing (measured through the WEMWBS scale) will be analysed through a paired samples t-test if normally distributed or nonparametric alternative. Multivariate analysis controlling for use, sense of place and socio-demographic characteristics will be carried out using ANOVA, with bootstrapping applied for non-normally distributed measures

registration_responses.q1: Out of Business. A survey investigation of the individual and community experiences and impact of the Douglas Village Shopping Centre Fire in Cork
registration_responses.q2: Marica Cassarino, Gillian Murphy, Annalisa Setti, Jason Chan, Eleanor Bantry-White
registration_responses.q3:
In August 2019, a major fire caused the closure of a shopping centre in Douglas, a suburban area of Cork city (Ireland). The  centre provided the community with a crucial space for a variety of leisure and utility activities. The Douglas Shopping Centre fire offers a unique opportunity to investigate the cognitive/affective experiences and the psychological/social impact of place loss from the perspective of both residents in the community and people working in the centre.

Key research questions include: 
1)	How was the shopping centre used (user type, destinations, frequency of use) and what meaning (Sense of place) did it have for individuals either using the centre as customers or working in the centre before the fire, considering the role of socio-demographic circumstances (e.g., age, functional capability, car access)
2)	Is the type of use of the centre associated with variations in sense of place? 
3)	How does event memory, flashbulb memory and emotional memory change after the reopening of the centre, and how is this related to sense of place, frequency of use, wellbeing, etc.?
4)	How does sense of place relate to the accuracy of remembered emotions concerning the fire?
5)	How did the closure of the shopping centre impact the individual (considering socio-demographic circumstances) in terms of everyday activities (utility and leisure; i.e. agency) and wellbeing (belonging)
6)	 What is the individual’s perceived impact of the centre closure on the community?
7)	Does perceived impact change over time?

H2: There will be variations in sense of place between users and employees of the shopping centre, with stronger sense of place for those both using the centre as customers and working there. 

H3: Memory accuracy for the fire will be higher for those more attached to the centre as well as those using it more frequently.

H5: The closure of the centre after the fire will have impacted more negatively those employed in the centre rather than those using it as users; however, people with vulnerabilities (e.g., older people with no car access) would also be more negatively impacted than others.

The first wave of data collection must occur before the re-opening of the centre, thus, data collection for wave 1 will be stopped once the centre re-opens (anticipated Summer 2020).

Qualitative data (questions 1, 5, 6) will be analysed employing thematic coding. attributes.title: Using fNIRS to measure how infants' brains respond to cues of close social affiliation
Solution-Focused Approaches
attributes.description: A series of studies testing key components of solution-focused coaching

q1.value: The effect of solution-focused coaching techniques on perceived goal attainability and commitment

q3.value: Although many popular books proclaim the effectiveness of solution-focused (SF) techniques, very few rigorous empirical studies have been conducted, and hardly any in a secondary school educational context. A series of studies will therefore be conducted to test various components of solution-focused coaching (e.g. scaling, solution-focused questions, focusing on resources and previous success, etc.)

q4.value:
Assuming the solution-focused techniques are effective, one may hypothesise the following:

1) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students asked to identify HOW successful they have been (at their most successful) on a scale from 0 to 10 (i.e. students who answer a scaling question) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who are merely asked to say WHETHER they have been successful (or not).

2) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students asked to identify HOW successful they have been (at their most successful) on a scale from 0 to 10 (i.e. students who answer a scaling question) are subsequently) more committed to the goal of improvement than students who are merely asked to say WHETHER they have been successful (or not).

3) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who answer a scaling question AND a follow-up solution-focused question (e.g. "What could you do to go up one point on the scale?") (i) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who merely answer a scaling question, and (ii) are more committed to the goal of improvement than students who merely answer a scaling questions

4) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who answer a scaling question and TWO follow-up solution-focused questions (i) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than (a) students who merely answer a scaling question and (b) students who answer a scaling question and ONE follow-up solution-focused question, and (ii) are more committed to the goal of improvement than (a) students who merely answer a scaling questions, and (b) students who answer a scaling question and ONE follow-up solution-focused question,

5) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who are asked solution-focused question (e.g. "What HELPS you in this area?") believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable and are more committed to the goal of improvement than students who are asked problem-focused questions (e.g. "What HOLDS YOU BACK in this area?")

6) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students who are asked a solution-focused question believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable and are more committed to the goal of improvement than students asked BOTH a solution-focused question AND a problem-focused question.

7) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students who are led to consider the area an "area for IMPROVEMENT" believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who are led to think of the area as a personal WEAKNESS.

8) The effect of scaling (and solution-focused) questions on commitment is mediated by changes in perceived goal attainability. That is, scaling and solution-focused questions raise perceived goal attainability, which in turn raises goal commitment.

9) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and answer solution-focused questions experience greater goal commitment than students who merely set goals.

10) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and answer solution-focused questions (including implementation intentions) make more progress towards their goals than students who merely set goals.

11) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and then engage in mental contrasting and form implementation intentions (a) experience greater goal commitment and (b) make more progress towards their goals than students who merely set goals.

12) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and take a wholly solution-focused approach (including implementation intentions) (a) experience greater commitment, and (b) make more progress towards their goals than students who set achievable, relevant goals and then engage in mental contrasting and form implementation intentions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: In all of these studies students are randomly assigned to conditions. The design of each experiment is therefore between-subjects. The experiment contrasting the "weakness" and "area for improvement" frames is a two-group study. The other experiments are three-group studies (e.g. no scaling vs. scaling vs. scaling + SF question). One of the experiments is a 2 x 2 factorial (the two factors being a) whether scaling is used, and b) whether the area asked about is a successful or unsuccessful one).

q9.value: Participants are randomised at the individual level. That is, each student will be randomly assigned to one of the conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: For some of the proposed experiments, students have submitted data electronically, which now reside in a safe online store. The researcher has checked to see that the data are actually in the store but the data have not yet been transferred to SPSS for analysis. The researcher therefore does not now whether the data support any of the hypotheses. For other experiments (e.g. that which involves mental contrasting and implementation intentions) no data have even been collected yet.

question.value: Students are invited to take part in the various studies via online surveys. The students are students in London secondary school. Students who volunteer to take part (i.e. those that give informed consent) will answer online surveys, thus producing data for the researcher to analyse. The data collection could last many months or even 1-2  years (particularly given the current Coronavirus which has meant that all schools have been closed). Data are collected for each study separately.

q13.value: The sample sizes for these studies range from approximately 100 to 120 (though the actual number of participants may be lower if some students opt out).

q14.value: The largest possible samples are used to maximise statistical power. This means that the studies will be made open to entire year groups.

question.value:
The manipulated variables differ from one experiment to the next but include:
1) Whether students answer scaling questions (e.g. "What is your highest level of success on a scale from 0 to 10?") or simple yes-no questions (e.g. "Are you succeeding? Or not succeeding?")
2) Whether students are asked to consider an area that is (a) going well, or (b) not going as well as they would like
3) Whether students are encouraged to think of an area as (a) an "area for improvement," or (b) a "weakness")
4) Whether students are asked (a) one SF question, (b) two SF questions, or (c) no SF questions
5) Whether students are asked (a) merely to set a goal, (b) to set a goal and answer SF questions, or (c) to set a goal, and engage in mental contrasting and implementation intentions
6) Whether students are asked (a) an SF question, (b) a PF question, or (c) an SF AND a PF question

The measured variables include:
1) Perceived Goal Attainability (PGA)
2) Goal Commitment (GC)
3) Perceived Goal Importance (PGI)
4) Perceived Stability
5) Perceived Controllability

For the between subjects 3 group studies, one-way ANOVAs will be used to test for mean differences in perceived goal attainability and commitment. An adjustment will be made to the alpha level to account for the fact that more than ANOVA is carried out. Mediation Analysis (using regression) will be used to test the mediational hypotheses. For the two group study ("weakness" vs. "area for improvement") MANOVA will be used since there are multiple dependent variables that are conceptually related.

q21.value: The alpha level will be the standard "p is less than 0.05"

q22.value: Boxplots and graphs will be used to detect outliers. Extreme scores will be removed from the data set prior to analysis.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete all the dependent measures, the data for that participant will not be included in the analysis

q24.value: If no significant results emerge from the univariate ANOVAs, a MANOVA may be performed to see whether a significant difference emerges. The reason why univariate ANOVAs will be performed first (for all studies except that comparing the "weakness" and "area for improvement" frame) is that the interest is in whether the manipulations affect each of the DVs separately. A MANOVA, however, may pick up a significant difference in a linear composite. But this will be labelled an exploratory result.

q25.value: The hypotheses that are advanced are consistent with popular "Solution-focused" theory. The researcher, however, would not wish to say that he is fully confident that the hypotheses will be supported. Indeed, the primary reason for these studies is to see whether (a) the popular enthusiasm for solution-focused approaches is merited, or (b) solution-focused approaches are in fact not as effective as many authors suggest.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of solution-focused coaching techniques on perceived goal attainability and commitment
registration_responses.q3: Although many popular books proclaim the effectiveness of solution-focused (SF) techniques, very few rigorous empirical studies have been conducted, and hardly any in a secondary school educational context. A series of studies will therefore be conducted to test various components of solution-focused coaching (e.g. scaling, solution-focused questions, focusing on resources and previous success, etc.)
registration_responses.q4:
Assuming the solution-focused techniques are effective, one may hypothesise the following:

1) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students asked to identify HOW successful they have been (at their most successful) on a scale from 0 to 10 (i.e. students who answer a scaling question) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who are merely asked to say WHETHER they have been successful (or not).

2) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students asked to identify HOW successful they have been (at their most successful) on a scale from 0 to 10 (i.e. students who answer a scaling question) are subsequently) more committed to the goal of improvement than students who are merely asked to say WHETHER they have been successful (or not).

3) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who answer a scaling question AND a follow-up solution-focused question (e.g. "What could you do to go up one point on the scale?") (i) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who merely answer a scaling question, and (ii) are more committed to the goal of improvement than students who merely answer a scaling questions

4) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who answer a scaling question and TWO follow-up solution-focused questions (i) believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than (a) students who merely answer a scaling question and (b) students who answer a scaling question and ONE follow-up solution-focused question, and (ii) are more committed to the goal of improvement than (a) students who merely answer a scaling questions, and (b) students who answer a scaling question and ONE follow-up solution-focused question,

5) When considering an unsatisfactory area of study, students who are asked solution-focused question (e.g. "What HELPS you in this area?") believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable and are more committed to the goal of improvement than students who are asked problem-focused questions (e.g. "What HOLDS YOU BACK in this area?")

6) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students who are asked a solution-focused question believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable and are more committed to the goal of improvement than students asked BOTH a solution-focused question AND a problem-focused question.

7) When considering an unsatisfactory area, students who are led to consider the area an "area for IMPROVEMENT" believe the goal of improvement to be more attainable than students who are led to think of the area as a personal WEAKNESS.

8) The effect of scaling (and solution-focused) questions on commitment is mediated by changes in perceived goal attainability. That is, scaling and solution-focused questions raise perceived goal attainability, which in turn raises goal commitment.

9) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and answer solution-focused questions experience greater goal commitment than students who merely set goals.

10) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and answer solution-focused questions (including implementation intentions) make more progress towards their goals than students who merely set goals.

11) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and then engage in mental contrasting and form implementation intentions (a) experience greater goal commitment and (b) make more progress towards their goals than students who merely set goals.

12) When working on a weekly study goal, students who set achievable, relevant goals and take a wholly solution-focused approach (including implementation intentions) (a) experience greater commitment, and (b) make more progress towards their goals than students who set achievable, relevant goals and then engage in mental contrasting and form implementation intentions.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants are randomised at the individual level. That is, each student will be randomly assigned to one of the conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: For some of the proposed experiments, students have submitted data electronically, which now reside in a safe online store. The researcher has checked to see that the data are actually in the store but the data have not yet been transferred to SPSS for analysis. The researcher therefore does not now whether the data support any of the hypotheses. For other experiments (e.g. that which involves mental contrasting and implementation intentions) no data have even been collected yet.
registration_responses.q13: The sample sizes for these studies range from approximately 100 to 120 (though the actual number of participants may be lower if some students opt out).
registration_responses.q14: The largest possible samples are used to maximise statistical power. This means that the studies will be made open to entire year groups.
registration_responses.q21: The alpha level will be the standard "p is less than 0.05"
registration_responses.q22: Boxplots and graphs will be used to detect outliers. Extreme scores will be removed from the data set prior to analysis.
registration_responses.q23: If a participant does not complete all the dependent measures, the data for that participant will not be included in the analysis
registration_responses.q24: If no significant results emerge from the univariate ANOVAs, a MANOVA may be performed to see whether a significant difference emerges. The reason why univariate ANOVAs will be performed first (for all studies except that comparing the "weakness" and "area for improvement" frame) is that the interest is in whether the manipulations affect each of the DVs separately. A MANOVA, however, may pick up a significant difference in a linear composite. But this will be labelled an exploratory result.
registration_responses.q25: The hypotheses that are advanced are consistent with popular "Solution-focused" theory. The researcher, however, would not wish to say that he is fully confident that the hypotheses will be supported. Indeed, the primary reason for these studies is to see whether (a) the popular enthusiasm for solution-focused approaches is merited, or (b) solution-focused approaches are in fact not as effective as many authors suggest.
registration_responses.q8.question: In all of these studies students are randomly assigned to conditions. The design of each experiment is therefore between-subjects. The experiment contrasting the "weakness" and "area for improvement" frames is a two-group study. The other experiments are three-group studies (e.g. no scaling vs. scaling vs. scaling + SF question). One of the experiments is a 2 x 2 factorial (the two factors being a) whether scaling is used, and b) whether the area asked about is a successful or unsuccessful one).
registration_responses.q12.question: Students are invited to take part in the various studies via online surveys. The students are students in London secondary school. Students who volunteer to take part (i.e. those that give informed consent) will answer online surveys, thus producing data for the researcher to analyse. The data collection could last many months or even 1-2  years (particularly given the current Coronavirus which has meant that all schools have been closed). Data are collected for each study separately.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The manipulated variables differ from one experiment to the next but include:
1) Whether students answer scaling questions (e.g. "What is your highest level of success on a scale from 0 to 10?") or simple yes-no questions (e.g. "Are you succeeding? Or not succeeding?")
2) Whether students are asked to consider an area that is (a) going well, or (b) not going as well as they would like
3) Whether students are encouraged to think of an area as (a) an "area for improvement," or (b) a "weakness")
4) Whether students are asked (a) one SF question, (b) two SF questions, or (c) no SF questions
5) Whether students are asked (a) merely to set a goal, (b) to set a goal and answer SF questions, or (c) to set a goal, and engage in mental contrasting and implementation intentions
6) Whether students are asked (a) an SF question, (b) a PF question, or (c) an SF AND a PF question
registration_responses.q17.question:
The measured variables include:
1) Perceived Goal Attainability (PGA)
2) Goal Commitment (GC)
3) Perceived Goal Importance (PGI)
4) Perceived Stability
5) Perceived Controllability
registration_responses.q19.question: For the between subjects 3 group studies, one-way ANOVAs will be used to test for mean differences in perceived goal attainability and commitment. An adjustment will be made to the alpha level to account for the fact that more than ANOVA is carried out. Mediation Analysis (using regression) will be used to test the mediational hypotheses. For the two group study ("weakness" vs. "area for improvement") MANOVA will be used since there are multiple dependent variables that are conceptually related.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
How Perceptions of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Vary by Individuals’ Levels of Critical Consciousness. 

We seek to understand how White adults’ critical consciousness, specifically their critical reflection, is associated to their beliefs and attitudes about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) and Native American people generally. Specifically, we will examine whether White individuals’ critical reflection is associated with 1) their beliefs about racism faced by Native Americans (i.e., racism minimization), 2) their prejudicial beliefs about Native Americans (i.e., cultural racism), 3) their dehumanization of Native Americans, and 4) their support for ending MMIWG. This work builds upon a separate study that found that critical consciousness–specifically critical reflection– was associated with positive intergroup outcomes in the context of Black-White relations, and so we aim to replicate these findings in a the Native American-White context.

sample.value: A power analysis revealed that we will need to collect responses from 1,000 participants.

analyses.value:
a.	Before conducting path models between our measures of interest, we will perform confirmatory factor analyses (CFA) to assess how well our survey items for critical reflection, racism minimization, cultural racism, and support for ending MMIWG measure our theoretical constructs– providing evidence of construct validity. Chi-squared, CFI ≥ .95, TLI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .06, and SRMR ≤ .08 will be used to assess our measurement models.
i.	If our measurement model does not converge, mean composites will be used in path analysis. 
ii.	The recommended cutoff marks (e.g., CFI ≥ .95) are not firm cutoff marks because there is no clear agreement as to whether there are any clear markers for assessing these fit indices in the SEM literature, rather these are rough rules of thumb that we will use to assess our models. A CFA of .93 or RMSEA of .07 for example, may be acceptable. 

b.	Path models will be conducted to test the hypotheses for primary research questions. Model fit will be assessed with chi-squared, CFI ≥ .95, TLI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .06, and SRMR ≤ .08.

c.	Mediation analysis using structural equation modeling will be employed to assess whether racism minimization and cultural racism mediate the link between critical reflection and support for ending MMIWG. We will use chi-squared, CFI ≥ .95, TLI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .06, and SRMR ≤ .08 to asses model fit.

dependent.value:
Racism Minimization, 3 items answered on a 1 (strongly disgaree) – 7 (strongly agree) scale. 

1.	Racism against Native Americans is a thing of the past.

2.	Being of the Native American race basically doesn't matter in society anymore. 

3.	Racial discrimination against Native Americans is not common in society. 


Cultural Racism, 13 items on a (1-Strongly Disagree to 7-Strongly Agree)
1.	The root cause of most of the social and economic ills of Native Americans is the weakness and instability of the Native American family.
2.	Although there are exceptions, Native American communities don’t seem to have strong community organization or leadership.
3.	On a whole, Native American people don’t stress education and training.
4.	Native Americans don’t seem to use opportunities to own and operate shops and businesses.
5.	Very few Native American people are looking for a free ride. (-1)
6.	Most Native Americans have the drive and determination to get ahead. (-1)
7.	Many Native American teenagers don’t respect themselves or anyone else.
8.	Native American children would do better in school if their parents had better attitudes about learning.
9.	Native Americans should take jobs that are available and then work their way up to better jobs.
10.	One of the biggest problems for a lot of Native Americans is their lack of self-respect.
11.	If Native Americans modernized and became more civilized, they would be more successful.
12.	Native American tendencies toward over-using alcohol and drugs are a central cause of their problems.
13.	The violence-prone nature of Native Americans plays a central role in the problems that they face.
 
Native Dehuminization, (0-Not at All to 100-Very Much)

To what extent do you think the following traits describe Native Americans, in general, as a group?

•	Responsible
•	Civilized
•	Moral
•	Polite
•	Childlike
•	Rational
•	Warm
•	Having agency
•	Promiscuous/sexual
•	Pure
•	Innocent
•	Savage
•	Primitive
•	Untamed/Wild

Support for MMIWG (Likert scale: 1 – Extremely unlikely, 2 – unlikely, 3 – Neutral, 4 – likely, 5 – Extremely likely)

In this section we are going to ask you about the likelihood that you would engage in the following activities. There are no right or wrong answers, so please answer with your gut instinct. 
1.	Share hashtag #MMIWG and other MMIWG materials on social media
2.	Write letters to your government representatives (e.g., city counselors, alder-people, congress people, senators) to request funding be allocated to address the issue of MMIWG.
3.	Donate money to groups working to end the MMIWG epidemic
4.	Vote for policies to increase Native American tribes’ authority to respond to the high rate of Native women being murdered and going missing
5.	Vote for policies to increase the ability of tribal courts to prosecute non-Native offenders
6.	Advocate for increased access to responsive law enforcement in rural tribal communities where Indigenous women and girls are going missing
7.	Advocate for required cultural sensitivity training for law enforcement to improve relationships with tribal communities with high rates of MMIWG

hypothesis.value:
We seek to understand how White adults’ critical consciousness, specifically their critical reflection, is associated to their beliefs and attitudes about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) and Native American people generally. Specifically, we will examine whether White individuals’ critical reflection is associated with 1) their beliefs about racism faced by Native Americans (i.e., racism minimization), 2) their prejudicial beliefs about Native Americans (i.e., cultural racism), 3) their dehumanization of Native Americans, and 4) their support for ending MMIWG. This work builds upon a separate study that found that critical consciousness–specifically critical reflection– was associated with positive intergroup outcomes in the context of Black-White relations, and so we aim to replicate these findings in a the Native American-White context. 


Hypotheses:

1.	Critical reflection among White participants will be negatively related to minimization of the racism Native Americans experience, controlling for political ideology. 

2.	Critical reflection among white participants will be negatively associated with cultural racism against Native Americans, controlling for political ideology.  

3.	Critical reflection among white participants will be negatively associated with Native American dehumanization, controlling for political ideology.  

4.	Critical reflection among white participants will be positively associated with support for ending MMIWG, controlling for political ideology.

5.	Decreases in racism minimization and cultural racism towards Native American people will mediate the link between critical reflection and support for ending MMIWG.

attributes.title: Labelless Self Bias
attributes.description: Self bias, seen in perceptual matching tasks, has been found to be stable across many settings. However, questions have been raised as to whether this is due to the label present. Therefore, is self bias seen in a perceptual matching task without labels?

q1.value: How does the self and stimuli valence interact in redundancy gains?

q3.value: The self prioritisation effect (enhanced performance when information is related to the self) has been widely found, however, the underlying mechanisms remain uncertain. Some argue that self prioritisation occurs due to self-related information being rewarding and hence reward mechanisms are activated. But, recent studies using redundancy gain experiments have found that reward and self related stimuli lead to different responses. This study aims to expand on these and integrate the self and reward within one stimuli to see how the interaction of the self being associated with positive or negative stimuli influences redundancy gains.

q4.value:
Explore the interaction between the self paired with positive and negative stimuli.

Tentative hypothesis: Self + Positive stimuli will lead to supercapacity in redundancy gains. 

Tentative hypothesis: Self + Negative stimuli will lead to limited capacity in redundancy gains.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

x within-subject factor trial type (3 levels: single reward vs single person vs combined) design.
